title: Adsorption et désorption du bore sur les sols et influence des apports de fumier
authors: N Zerrari; D Moustaoui; Marc Verloo
abstract: Les phenomenes d'adsorption et de desorption du bore ont ete etudies selon les isothermes de Langmuir et de Freundlich sur du fumier de ferme et sur onze sols dont deux comportent egalement un enrichissement en fumier. Les donnees obtenues ont montre que ces phenomenes sont bien decrits par les isothermes utilises (r variant entre 0,902 * * * et 0,999 * * * ). Les capacites d'adsorption maximales observees pour les sols varient entre 23,98 et 102,04 pg B/g de sol avec une moyenne de 60,38 pour tous les sols compris et des relations significatives sont apparues entre ces capacites d'adsorption en bore et certaines caracteristiques des sols dont la teneur en argile (r = 0,730 * * ), en matiere organique (r = 0,615 * ) et la capacite d'echange cationique (r = 0,852 * * * ). Le fumier a presente une capacite d'adsorption maximale qui a ete de 312,50 μg B/g de fumier et qui represente entre 3 et 13 fois celle des sols etudies et l'apport de fumier aux sols a entraine une augmentation importante de leurs capacites d'adsorption. Un effet d'hysteresis, faible toutefois dans le cas du fumier et au contraire important dans le cas des sols, apparait pour l'ensemble des substrats etudies lorsque les phenomenes de desorption sont compares a ceux de l'adsorption. Le fumier a presente un indice de desorption moyen qui a ete de 1,5183; valeur non loin de 1 qui caracterise la reversibilite des phenomenes d'adsorption. Les indices de desorption moyens observes pour les sols varient entre 1,9771 et 4,7639 avec une moyenne de 3,3152 pour tous les sols compris et des relations significatives sont apparues entre ces indices et certaines caracteristiques des sols dont la teneur en matiere organique (r = -0,787 * * ) et la capacite d'echange cationique (r = -0,709 * * ). L'incorporation du fumier aux sols a entraine une diminution importante de leurs indices de desorption.

title: Release and potential bioavailability of phosphorus in runoff and erosion from a scrubland reconverted to pasture
authors: R. Basanta; B. Soto; Francisco Dı́az-Fierros Viqueira
abstract: Field assays in standard experimental plots were performed to investigate phosphorus losses from hill slope scrubland plots following clearance and conversion to pasture. About 90% of total phosphorus losses in runoff over the study period were in the fine-particle-associated phosphorus fraction. Since 89% of total bioavailable phosphorus losses in runoff (by extraction with 0.11 M NaOH) were in particulate form, particle-associated-phosphorus clearly makes a major contribution to diffuse pollution. Vegetation cover was a key factor: once cover exceeded 70-80%, fine particle erosion in runoff dropped below the detection limit (0.01 g 1 - 1 ). As a consequence, the benefits of phosphate application can be considered to outweigh the disadvantages.

title: Metolachlor and linuron soil degradation after repeated applications under laboratory conditions
authors: Cesare Accinelli; Giovanni Dinelli; Alberto Vicari; R. Mallegni
abstract: The effects of short-time repeated treatments of metolachlor [2-chloro-6'-ethyl-N-(2-methoxy-1-memylethyl)aceto-o-toluidide] and linuron [3-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)-1-methoxy-1-methylurea] on their degradation rate and soil biomass C were investigated under laboratory conditions. Short-time repeated applications of linuron and metolachlor caused enhanced degradation of the two chemicals. The effect was stable for linuron and transient for metolachlor. In soil samples receiving from one to five short-time repeated treatments of metolachlor or linuron, no significant decrease of biomass C with respect to control soil was observed. A decrease of soil biomass C was observed in soil samples receiving an additional metolachlor or linuron treatment which was done 160 days from the previous one. This study suggests that degradation of two different herbicides can be forced to accelerate rates by repeated short-time applications of the same active ingredient, although magnitude and persistence of the phenomenon depends on the type of herbicides.

title: Comparison of ashing procedures for the determination of trace elements in plant leaves
authors: Filip Tack; SP Singh; Marc Verloo
abstract: Ashing procedures for the determination of trace elements in plant leaves and needles were compared. Both the ashing temperature and element dissolution procedure affected the analytical results, but to a different extent depending on the element and plant considered, Ashing procedures which have proven to be suitable for mayor element determination, may not be used indiscriminately for the determination of trace elements in plant materials, The procedure that involves ashing at 450 degrees C and taking up the ash in 6M HNO3 seemed the best compromise.

title: Uptake of metals in maize as affected by irrigation water quality and clay content of the soil
authors: SP Singh; Filip Tack; Marc Verloo
abstract: A pot experiment was carried out under controlled conditions to evaluate the combined effects of chemical oxygen demand (C.O.D.) and heavy metal content in synthetic irrigation water and clay content of the soil on the metal uptake by maize plants, Maize (Zea Mag's L.) was grown during 30 days on two soils, an acidic sandy soil and the same soil amended with 5% polder clay, These soils were continuously irrigated with synthetic irrigation water before and during plant growth, The dry matter yield of maize decreased and heavy metal concentrations in the plant tissue increased with increasing heavy metal concentration in the irrigation water. A higher C.O.D. concentration in the irrigation water also resulted in an overall increase of the dry matter yield and metal concentrations in the plant tissue. Addition of 5% clay to the acidic soil reduced these effects. The clay content of the soil was by far the most important factor in controlling plant growth and metal uptake.

title: LES FORMES DU BORE DES SOLS : IMPORTANCE, EFFET DES CARACTERISTIQUES DES SOLS ET DISPONIBILITE POUR LES PLANTES
authors: N Zerrari; D Moustaoui; Marc Verloo
abstract:
The study has been carried out on eleven soils using both soil analysis and a greenhouse pot experiment. Soil boron has been determined according to the hot water method and fractioned in five distinct fractions. The greenhouse experiment was carried out according to the Neubauer technic using barley as the plant test. 
Hot water boron represents 0.81% of total boron. The > and > fractions are negligible and represent together 1.18% of total boron. The residual fraction constitutes the most important fraction and represents 78.75%. Intermediate fractions represent together 20.08%, of which 8.04% is bound to oxydes and 12.04% is bound to organic matter. 
The soil characteristics that most influenced the different forms of soil boron are cation exchange capacity, texture, organic matter and pH. Highly significant correlations have been observed between these soil characteristics and some forms of soil boron. 
Boron uptake by barley was higher than the quantities of boron corresponding to the > and > fractions. This means that other forms, including organic matter bound-form and probably also oxydes bound-form, participated in boron nutrition of the plants.

title: The influence of peat content on water retention in the substrata of some golf course greens. Determination from mathematical models
authors: Josefina C. Tapias; M. Salgot
abstract: During recent years many golf courses have been constructed along the Mediterranean coast. More are still planned in spite of water resources being insufficient for other existing essential uses. Water demand for such courses (quantity and frequency) depends on the hydraulic properties of the soil in addition to the climatic characteristics of the locality and type of vegetation introduced. For this reason it is considered essential as a water saving strategy to specifically determine the hydraulic properties of the substrates that are most often used to build golf greens. For the efficient management of irrigation on golf courses it is necessary to have a good knowledge of the soil moisture characteristics. These are intrinsically related to the matrix where water is retained. The behaviour of water in the soil, and its availability to be extracted by the plants, is mainly determined by the pF curves which mainly depend on soil composition, texture and organic matter content. The behaviour of soil moisture characteristic curves for sands are tested for differing amounts of peat content, often used as substrate for building green's golf courses. Siliceous sand with a 20% (v/v) of peat is shown to have the highest amount of water reserve available for grass development.

title: Effect of soil dunging on absorption of iron, copper, zinc and manganese
authors: D Moustaoui; Marc Verloo
abstract:
The objective of this rearch was the study of the effect of mature application on the behaviour of iron, copper, manganese and zinc in the soil with and without addition of these four elements in a greenhouse pot experiment using wheat as the plant control. 
The results of this study showed that the status of these micronutrients was different after manure application. 
Plant analyses showed that iron, zinc and manganese concentrations increased with increasing rates of applied manure up to 2.0% and decreased when the applied manure reached 4.0%. The observed increase varied from 22.7 to 192.8%, 19.8 to 82.1%, and 3.2 to 15.1% for iron, zinc and manganese respectively. 
The behaviour of copper was different from that of iron, zinc and manganese, in that the addition of manure associated with that of copper induced a significant decrease in copper concentration in the plant which varied from 7.1 to 50.0%. However, when no copper was added, manure applications induced an increase in plant copper concentration which varied from 11.7 to 58.8%.

title: Interaction Olivier-Psylle: caractérisation des composés phénoliques des jeunes pousses et des grappes florales et relation avec le degré d'attraction ou de répulsion des cultivars
authors: N. Zouiten; Y. Ougass; Abdelkader Hilal; Nicole Ferrière; Jean‐Jacques Macheix; I. El Hadrami
abstract: L'analyse des composes phenoliques des jeunes pousses et des grappes florales de l'Olivier est decrite ici pour la premiere fois en relation avec l'attaque du Psylle: #Euphyllura olivina# Costa (Homopteres Psyllidae), insecte suceur de la seve elaboree. Des differences quantitatives ont ete relevees en comparant les extraits phenoliques de 7 cultivars etudies pour leur degre d'attraction ou de repulsion vis-a-vis de l'insecte ravageur. Globalement, les jeunes pousses et les grappes florales des cultivars les plus repulsifs presentent des teneurs elevees en phenols par rapport aux cultivars les plus attractifs vis-a-vis de l'insecte. Parmi les nombreux composes phenoliques mis en evidence, le 3,4 dihydroxyphenylethanol parait etre positivement relie a la repulsion des cultivars. Par ailleurs, il ressort que l'attraction preferentielle de l'insecte par les grappes florales durant la periode de floraison peut etre expliquee, en partie, par leur teneur 2 a 3 fois plus faible en phenols par comparaison aux jeunes pousses. De meme, ce travail revele que les degâts les plus importants (chute des jeunes pousses, des grappes florales et des jeunes fruits) ont lieu durant la periode ou le materiel vegetal presente une faible teneur en phenols. L'importance des composes phenoliques dans le phenomene d'attraction ou de repulsion de l'insecte par les cultivars d'Olivier est discutee.

title: Yield response and nitrogen accumulation of furrow-irrigated Burley tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum L.) under deficit irrigation. Preliminary results
authors: Maria Isabella Sifola
abstract: A field experiment was conducted using furrow-irrigated Burley tobacco (cv. C104) to compare two deficit irrigation treatments with a full irrigation treatment (control). Two deficit irrigation treatments (50% ETC), imposed either using every row deficit irrigation (DI 50 ) or partial root-zone drying (PRD 50 ), were compared with a full irrigation treatment (100% ETC, FI control). In the DI 50 treatment plants received half of the volume of water uniformly applied to both sides of the row, whereas in the PRD 50 treatment one-half of the root zone was wetted while the other half was maintained dry, thereby the half amount of irrigation water was applied; in particular, the wetted and dry zones were interchanged in two subsequent irrigations. The yield of cured leaves of DI 50 and PRD 50 treatments was 69 and 90% of that of the control, respectively. The dry matter at commercial harvest of DI 50 and PRD 50 was 56 and 88% of the control, respectively. The irrigation water use efficiency (IWUE) of DI 50 and PRD 50 treatments, expressed as kg of cured leaves ha -1 mm -1 of water applied, was 136 and 179% of the control, respectively. At commercial harvest, N accumulated by both DI 50 and PRD 50 plants was 40% or negligible less, respectively, than that accumulated by FI plants. PRD 50 plants showed a greater accumulation of NO 3 -N than plants of other treatments in the second part of growth, although differences were significant with respect to DI 50 but not to FI plants. Considering leaves only, NO 3 -N content showed a trend similar to that reported for the whole plant. Deficit irrigation practice, and PRD 50 in particular, appears an interesting method to supply and save water for Burley tobacco grown in semi-arid areas.

title: Effects of Cd on ectomycorrhizal fungal growth. Efficacy of in vitro screening experiment
authors: Aricia Evlard; Bruno Campanella; Roger Paul
abstract: The effects of Cd on growth as biomass production of forty-seven ectomycorrhizal fungal strains (ECM) were studied in vitro in liquid medium. These strains were collected from the roots of alders and willows located along waterways in regions of the Walloon area of Belgium where there is a low anthropogenic Cd contamination or where there is a naturally high background of Cd of geological origin. Using an in vitro test is practical for screening quickly several ECM fungal strains. The ECM fungal strains studied here showed a variability of responses to the presence of Cd. Most of the strains did not seem to be affected by Cd. In addition, most of the sensitive strains showed a significantly reduced biomass production with increasing Cd concentrations and these came from the soils of Hainaut and Namur. This observation would suggest that elevated Cd concentrations in soils of origin might play a role in selection pressure in the ECM fungal community.

title: Long Term Effect of Land Use Systems on Phosphorus Adsorption Behaviour under Acidic Alfisol of Meghalaya, India.
authors: B. Majumdar; M. S. Venkatesh; Rajib Saha
abstract: Phosphorus adsorption behaviour of five land use systems viz. Livestock based land-use (FSl), Forestry (FS2), Agriculture (FS3), Agri-horti- silvipastoral (FS4) and Natural fallow (FS5) regularly receiving/not receiving fertilizer P and manure was studied after 17 years of their establishment on an acid Alfisol on hilly slopes. The soils of various land-use systems varied widely in their P sorption behaviour with variable P built up in different systems. The P sorption was higher in the soils of natural fallow land-use system and progressively decreased with the application of manures/P + manures in livestock, agri-horti-silvipastoral and agriculture land-use. Phosphate sorption data fitted well to the classical Langmuir adsorption isotherm equation. Different land-use systems had no effect on adsorption maxima (b) while, bonding energy (k), maximum phosphate buffering capacity (MPBC) and standard P requirement (SPR) were highest for natural fallow followed by forestry land use. In contrast, livestock, agri-horti-silvipastoral and agriculture land-use recorded lower values of these P adsorption parameters indicating higher P availability in these systems. The P fractionation before and after equilibrium with added P showed a wide variation in the build up of various forms of P in different land-use systems which reflected in the variable adsorption of P in these land-use systems under study.

title: Effects of three years of pig slurry application on the distribution and contents of exchangeable K in three different soil types in the plain of Piacenza.
authors: Claudio Baffi; Antonio Nassisi; Simona Giosuè; Chiara Cassinari
abstract: Variations in exchangeable (K exch ), amount of recovery of in the soil, of the uptake and of recovery in the crops, and the amounts of unaccounted- in the soil-plant system, have been determined for three soil types with different textures, CEC, pH, and lime content. These soils were fertilized with pig slurry for three consecutive years, in different periods, at a constant rate of 0.6 t N ha -1 year -1 in experi- mental plots cropped with maize (Zea mays L.). The increases of soil K.,ch observed for soil 3 (clay with △ MAX exch estimated 162.6 mg kg -1 ) showed values significantly (P < 0.01) greater than the other two soils (soil 2 silty-clay-loam with a value estimated for △ max exch 72.6 mg kg -1 and soil 1 silt-loam with estimated △ Max ;K exch , 38.1 mg kg -1 ). The difference in the estimated cumulated amounts of exch among the three soil types is due to the higher clay content and C.E.C. of soil 3, and to the higher slope values present in soils 1 and 2 respect to soil 3. For soil 3 only a sig-nificant inverse correlation (P < 0.01 and r = -0.945) was observed between △K exch and applied with slurry. The amounts of taken up by the crops were only slightly cor-related with the applied K: soil 2 (r = 0.804; tot. rec. = 33.3% K), soil 1 (r = 0.785; tot. rec. = 35.6% K) and soil 3 (r = 0.581 ; tot. rec. = 39.8% K). The values of unaccounted-for were, on average, significantly lower (P < 0.01) for soil 3 (17.4%) compared to soil 1 (58.3%) and soil 2 (59.5%). Only for soil 3 a significant correlation (P < 0.05) was found between unaccounted for- K and the amount of applied (r = 0.957).

title: Soil organic matter increase: Comparison between two strategies
authors: Maria Costanza Andrenelli; E. Batistoni; G. Brandi; R. Papini; Sergio Pellegrini; Raimondo Piccolo; Nadia Vignozzi
abstract: The effects of different management practices, such as the traditional tillage system (deep ploughing) with compost addition, and a conservative one (minimum tillage), on soil organic matter and macroporosity are investigated. A three-year research (2005-2007) was performed on a silty clay loam soil under sorghum (Sorghum bicolor L.) continuous cropping. The comparison between the experimental data of the first and the third year, at the end of each cropping season, shows a significant increase in both total extractable (TEC) and humic organic carbon (HC) at 0÷10 and 15÷25 cm depth, for the compost treatment (COM) only. In minimum tillage (MT) a noteworthy raise is observed for total organic carbon (TOC) in the upper layer, while all the chemical parameters remain constant in both the layers of the control soil (T). As a whole, COM and MT soils exhibit the best structure. In COM a noticeable percentage of elongated transmission pores is mostly represented, probably related to high humic fraction amounts. In T low macroporosity values point out the occurrence of compact soil.

title: Disposal of industrial lump sulphur by-product in soil. Influence on soil chemical and biochemical properties and on yield and quality of sugar beet (Beta vulgaris L)
authors: P. Perucci; I. Beldomenico; E. Buongarzone; Cristiano Casucci; G. S. Cecca; Elga Monaci; R. Santilocchi; Costantino Vischetti
abstract: A field experiment was carried out to evaluate modifications on the chemical and biochemical parameters of an agricultural alkaline soil (pH=8.31) under sugar beet (Beta vulgaris L.) by applying different amounts of sulphur by-product coming from oil desulphurization process. Soil chemical properties such as sulphate formation, pH, soil electrical conductivity (EC), total and extractable organic carbon (TOC and TEC), and biochemical parameters such as microbial biomass carbon content (MBC) and total hydrolytic capacity (FDA-hydrolysis), arylsulphatase (ArS-ase) and o-diphenoloxidase (o-DPO), were monitored. Commercial parameters of yield and quality production of sugar beet (yield of roots, % of polarization, extractable saccharose content and purity of thick juice) were also determined. All soil chemical and biochemical properties and commercial parameters of sugar beet were monitored in plots treated with 1 (S1), 5 (S5) and 10 (S10) t ha -1 of sulphur by-product and compared with untreated plots (SO). In S1, 60 days after amendment the highest values of sulphate formed (310 mg kg -1 ) and the EC (1596 μS cm -1 ), were observed. In S5, the sulphate formed was 2583 mg kg' and soil EC was 4138 μS cm -1 after 210 days, while in S10 the amount of sulphur added probably exceeded soil oxidation capacity since it continued more slowly till the end of the experiment. After 210 days, soil pH reached the lowest value in all the treated plots and it was 7.75, 7.52 and 7.26 in S1, S5 and S10, respectively. No significant modifications were made on soil biochemical parameters tested by the different amounts of sulphur added. A decrease in the production yield of sugar beet (27.2%) was found only when the highest amount of sulphur was applied. In contrast, no worsening of main commercial parameters was observed.

title: Identification of reaction products of phosphate fertilizers with soil using chemical and FTIR-PAS methods.
authors: T. Wang; H. Y. Wang; Jiacong Zhou
abstract: Due to its applicability for highly absorbing solid samples without any special pre-treatment, Fourier transform infrared photoacoustic spectroscopy (FTIR- PAS) is preferable to analyze soil properties. In the present work, the reaction products of monocalcium phosphate monohydrate (MCP), monoammonium phosphate (MAP) and diammonium phosphate (DAP) within a Mollisol were identified using chemical fractionation and FTIR-PAS. It was found in chemical fractionation that aluminum phosphate (Al-P) was the main reaction product in MAP and MCP treatments; but in DAP treatment, water soluble P (We-P) was the dominant fraction. Compared with the broad interpretation of P forms in chemical fractionation, FTIR-PAS combined with partial least square (PLS) regression model can give us deep sight about the mineral phase of P in each broad fraction. In the work, the contents of variSci.te predicted by the PLS model in MCP and DAP treatments were significantly correlated to that of Al-P measured in chemical fractionation (P< 0.01), indicating the presence of variSci.te in Al-P fraction in MCP and DAP treatments.

title: Microbial respiration and dependency under different management systems in semiarid region of northern Turkey.
authors: Rasim Koçyiğit
abstract: The objective of this study was to evaluate basal (BR) and specific respirations (qCO 2 ) of soils under native pasture and long-term cultivated soils at semiarid climate of the northern Turkey. In addition, the dependencies of BR to soil water content and the relationship between microbial biomass C (Cmic) and qCO 2 were determined in both ecosystems. Specific respiration was calculated as BR/C mic . BR varied through growth season in the both ecosystems and native pasture generally had greater BR than long-term cultivated soil. The highest BR was observed in October at native pasture. However, qCO 2 was generally greater in long-term cultivated soil compared to native pasture. qCO 2 and C mic were negatively correlated at all layers of both management systems. There was not a significant dependency between soil water content and BR in Fluvaquentic Haplustolls. Thus, long-term cultivation increased qCO 2 which varied through growth season. Soil organisms under stress condition increased qCO 2 compared to native pasture.

title: Impact of sewage sludge amendment on heavy metal in soils of maize field.
authors: Ed Yong; Song GuoLi; Wei Bian; Xiaolin Zhang
abstract: The modified three-step sequential extraction procedure proposed by the Community Bureau of Reference (BCR) was used to predict Cd, Cu and Zn fractional distribution in maize soil amended with sludge at doses of 10 Mg-hm -2 , 30 Mg-hm -2 and 60 Mg-hm -2 . The heavy metals in soils amended with sludge were mainly associated with the residual fraction. The exchangeable and weak acid soluble fraction order of the metals in a slightly acidic soil was: Cd≈Zn≫Cu. According to our modified Risk Assessment Code (RAC), for the soils amended with sludge at dose from 2 to 6 times the regular amount, there was a medium risk concerning Cd and Zn, and in the case of 12 times the regular amount there was high risk. The safe period of sludge continuous amendment should be considered at least of 6 years.

title: Effects of slow release fertilizers on nutrient status and fruit quality of the peach cultivar Andross (Prunus persica L. Batch)
authors: Nikolaos Koutinas; Thomas Sotiropoulos; Chrysovalantou Antonopoulou; Ioannis Therios; C. Stavrou
abstract: The scope of the present research was to study the effects of slow release fertilizers compared to common fertilizers in terms of nutrient status and fruit quality of the peach cultivar Andross. Trees that were fertilized with 24.5 nitrogen (N) units (kg 0.1 ha -1 ) showed very high soil total N concentrations. When 15.5 and 20.5 N units were applied in forms of 21-8-11 and 15-15-15 slow release fertilizers, soil total N concentrations were found within the sufficiency range. Fruit weight was lower when 24.5 N units applied compared to 20.5 and 15.5 N units. The lowest preharvest fruit drop was recorded at 15.5 N units, whereas high percentages were measured at 24.5 N units. The length of shoots at the 24.5 N units was excessive, leading to shading of the lower branches. Significant correlations were computed between total soil N of the sampling of August of 2007 and leaf N (r 2 = 0.71, significant at P<0.001 ), fruit weight (r 2 = -0.57, significant at P<0.001), leaf chlorophyll content (r 2 = 0.66, significant at P<0.001), shoot length (r 2 = 0.59, significant at P<0.001), fruit firmness (r 2 = -0.51, significant at P<0.001) and total soluble solids (r 2 = 0.48, significant at P<0.001). In conclusion, application of 15.5 N units supported by 15-15-15 and 26-0-0 slow release fertilizers, contributes for having adequate N during the whole vegetative period for tree growth and development and the attainment of high productivity.

title: The effect of phosphate deficiency on sugars and organic acids accumulation in bean roots
authors: Marco Antonio Russo; Eligio Malusà; Adalgisa Belligno
abstract: The objective of this study was to evaluate the influence of phosphate deficiency on malate dehydrogenase activity and on sugars and organic acids concentrations in bean roots (Phaseolus vulgaris L.) plants. In P-deficient plants, glucose and fructose concentration were always higher than in control plants. The sucrose concentration in roots of both P-deficient and P sufficient plants was similarly increasing during the experiment. The concentration of the organic acids determined was always higher in the roots of P-deficient plants as compared to +P plants. The root total malate dehydrogenase (MDH) activity was similar in P-deficient and control plants up to 18 days of growth. On the other hand, the activity of the mitochondrial isoforms in -P plants was lower than in the control. The higher soluble sugars concentration in P deficient roots is an evident symptom of the reduction of the catabolism of the carbon photosynthates.

title: Effect of culture conditions on Sinorhizobium fredii and plant inoculation efficiency
authors: Fabiola Pagliero; R. Castaño; D. Mariani; M. Pastor; Graciela Susana Lorda
abstract: Obtention of high cell-concentration inoculants produced under different conditions leads to products that can be used under different soil and weather conditions. The aim of this work was to study the physiological and molecular characteristics of fast-growing rhizobia strain under different osmolarity, pH and aeration conditions. In addition, the symbiotic performance of strain under greenhouse conditions has been taken into consideration. Initial values of pH 6, aeration of 367 O 2 .l-1.h-1, and osmolarity of 100 mM NaCl were chosen as combined stress conditions for the cultivation of the strain. High concentration of cell suspensions was obtained after their adaptation to different stress conditions, reaching values of 109cfu/ml approximately. It was established that - under such conditions - cell LPSs profiles were not modified. However, the concentration of biosynthesized EPS increased under adverse conditions of growth (pH 6 and osmolarity of 50-100 mM) contrarily to what happened with the controls (pH 7 and 2 mM NaCl). Moreover, the symbiotic potential of fast-growing soybean rhizobia, obtained in adverse conditions for bacterial growth, has been evaluated. None of the rhizobia produced nodules with the American soybean cultivar under greenhouse, because these cellular suspensions did not meet the conditions required for them to be used as inoculants. On the other hand, soybean plants inoculated with the reference fast-growing strains SMH12 demonstrated good nodulation (170 nodules /pot). Even though statistic analysis did not show significant differences in data obtained from % dry weight and % nitrogen, plants showed, nevertheless, a great development and high nitrogen content in all the tests in which they had been inoculated, as compared with the non-inoculated control this was produced independently of the condition in which the bacterial strain was obtained we can conclude that the tests performed with s.fredii usda205 show a pgpr (growth promoting) effect on soybean plantS instead of a nitrogen fixation symbiotic relationship, evidenced by the absence of nodulation in all of the tests.

title: Nitrogen mineralization of sewage sludge from three waste water treatment plants of Greece.
authors: Dafni Ioannou; C. H. Kallianou
abstract: In this paper, nitrogen mineralization of sewage sludge from three waste water treatment plants of Greece (KAT, LAR, KAL) was studied. For this reason, incubation experiment of sludge was carried out in the laboratory, lasting 156 days for KAT and LAR sludge and 198 days for KAL sludge. The samples were leached periodically with CaCl 2 and N-free nutrient solution and the concentration of NH + 4- N and NO - 3- N was determined in the leachates. NO - 3- N was the predominant fraction. The mineralized nitrogen (Nm) can be described by a first order kinetics model obtained by a non linear regression analysis. The amount of Nm produced, was greater in KAL sludge, followed by LAR and KAT. The potentially mineralizable nitrogen (No) follows the order NoKAT<NoLAR< NoKAL, which was probably attributed to the degree of polymerization of the organic matter and the percent of total nitrogen and of humic acid's N.

title: Morphological and chemical fingerprinting of Sweet Basil (Ocimum basilicum L.) genotypes grown in sodic soil
authors: Rakesh Kumar Gautam; A. K. Nayak; Devender Sharma; Ali Qadar; Pradip Dey; G. Singh
abstract: A field experiment was conducted in sodic soil during rainy seasons of 2003 and 2004 to evaluate five diverse accessions of Ocimum basilicum for 15 plant traits, herb and oil yields and detailed analysis of chemical constituents of the oil. Statistically higher biomass yield was recorded in CSLT12, CSLT9 and CSLT13 as compared to other germplasms. However, oil yield in CSLT13 was almost double than in CSLT9 and CSLT12, thus indicating that the higher herbage yield does not always result in a higher oil yield. CSLT5 was of the linalool chemotype (European type) yielding more than 60% linalool in its oil whereas CSLT13 and CSLT9 could be classified as methyl chavicol chemotypes (Reunion types) yielding 68% and 56% of methyl chavicol, respectively. The accessions CSLT12 and CSLT12-1 were found as Bulgarian types which yielded more than 41% of methyl chavicol and 29% of linalool with appreciable content (> 5.00%) of methyl cinnamate. The presence of other important mono- and sesqui- terpenes in these genotypes was also investigated and discussed. The study reports detailed morpho-chemical characterization, herb and oil yields obtained from different plant parts of basil genotypes grown in sodic soil of pH 2 9.3.

title: Soil biological activities during the bioremediation of diesel contaminated soils
authors: Roberto Cardelli; Raffaella Di Puccio; A. Saviozzi
abstract: The responses of six agricultural soils, different in chemical, physical and biological characteristics, to diesel contamination were monitored during a 90-d incubation period. An evaluation of some enzyme activities and soil basal respiration as biological soil parameters to monitor soil status and quality during the decontamination process from total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPH) was carried out. Three samples were used: S (control, uncontaminated soil), CS (contaminated soil), SCS (sterilized contaminated soil). The relationships between soil parameters and the levels of TPH residues were investigated. Results showed large loss of TPH, ranging between 28% and 40%, due to volatilization in all treatments during the first 10-d incubation period. The most effective biodegradation ability was in organic and coarse-textured soils. TPH strongly inhibited enzyme activities, mainly lipase and dehydrogenase. The soil respiration dynamics was reproduced satisfactorily by a kinetic model able to fit a flush of C mineralization followed by a stabilization phase. β-glucosidase activity and basal respiration were the best biochemical parameters for monitoring soil status and quality during the bioremediation process.

title: Response of peanut to moisture stress and irrigation.
authors: A. R. Khan; Badal Kumar Datta
abstract: The response of groundnuts cv. SB XI to 3 irrigation depths (2, 4 and 6 cm) and I:E ratios (0.50, 0.75 and 1.00) was studied in a glasshouse on a sandy loam soil for 2 consecutive years. The I:E ratio is the ratio between a fixed depth of irrigation water and cumulative pan evaporation from Class A open pan, less rainfall since previous irrigation. Yield components and pod yield were significantly affected by both irrigation depth and I:E ratio. Water use efficiency was higher in the 2nd year. The higher I:E ratio proved to be inferior in terms of water use efficiency. I:E ratio of 0.75 was recommended for cv. SB XI as the optimum irrigation index for potential yield and water use efficiency in the prevailing agroclimatic conditions. To ensure adequate moisture in the effective root zone, 6 cm net irrigation was considered to be the best irrigation depth

title: Growth, proteins and nutrients of two wheat varieties in response to field drought
authors: Riccardo Izzo; M. Di Leo; Gianfranco Venora; Matteo Antonio Russo; Adalgisa Belligno
abstract: The response of Triticum durum Desf metabolism and growth to field water deficit conditions was investigated in a less drought tolerant cv. (Valnova) and a more drought tolerant cv. (Simeto). Plants were grown without irrigation in a Mediterranean environment, characterised by dry-hot conditions. The two cvs showed differences in height, fresh and dry matter production. The total amount of proteins, as well as K, Ca, and Mg contents, in leaves, culms and kernels were always significantly higher in Simeto, with protein and K increasing in seeds and culms of both cvs.

title: Soil biological activities during hydrocarbon degradation of a diesel-contaminated soil in the presence of surfactant
authors: R. Riffaldi; Roberto Cardelli; Sara Palumbo; R. Levi-Minzi; A. Saviozzi
abstract: The total petroleum hydrocarbon (TPH) degradation and the related soil biological activities in a diesel-contaminated soil were monitored during a 60-d incubation period in a laboratory study. Three treatments were carried out: uncontaminated soil (S) (control), soil contaminated with 10,000mg of diesel oil kg -1 of soil (CS), and contaminated soil plus surfactant Tween 80 at 3% w/w (CSS). Microbial respiration, seed germination index, and dehydrogenase, β-glucosidase, and lipase enzyme activities were monitored during incubation. The relationships between soil biological parameters and the TPH levels of the total were investigated. Results indicate that the extent of TPH degradation, of about 50% either in CS and CSS, resulted positively related with microbial respiration and negatively with soil lipase activity. The hydrocarbons depressed seed germination index, while the addition of the surfactant showed a positive effect, counterbalancing the negative influence of TPH. The addition of the surfactant increased the degradation rate of hydrocarbons, microbial respiration and dehydrogenase and lipase activities, as well as germination index, while it had no effect on β-glucosidase activity. The best biochemical parameters for testing hydrocarbon degradation and for monitoring the contamination of diesel oil polluted soil were lipase activity and soil respiration.

title: Seasonal accumulation of mineral nutrients in leaves of kiwifruit vines irrigated with high boron water
authors: Thomas Sotiropoulos; Ioannis Therios; K. Dimassi
abstract: The objective of the present research was to study the effect of B toxicity on seasonal accumulation of nutrients in leaves of kiwifruit vines. Two experimental orchards (A and B) were used. Orchard (A) was irrigated withhigh B water (3.2 mg B L - 1 ) while orchard (B) which served as control was irrigated with good quality water (0.3 mg B L - 1 ). The seasonal patterns for the various macro and micronutrients could be broadly grouped into four types. The first of these patterns was for potassium. Potassium concentration of leaves declined steadily throughout the season in both orchards. The second pattern was for nitrogen, phosphorus and zinc, where the high concentrations in the leaves during the first sampling date declined rapidly during the following 3 sampling dates to reach values which remained relatively constant for the remainder of the season for both orchards. The third pattern was for magnesium, iron and manganese. The concentrations of these elements in leaves declined during the first and the second sampling date but then increased for the remainder of the season. The fourth pattern was for boron and calcium. The concentrations of these elements in leaves increased steadily throughout the season. With regards to the effect of B toxicity on the concentration of the rest nutrients, it was found that leaf K, N, P, Mg and Zn concentrations were not significantly affected, whereas Ca and Mn concentrations decreased indicating that B toxicity affects Ca and Mn absorption and/or transport.

title: Evaluation of total and bioavailable heavy metals and other soil-related variables in a rice paddy after the application of defecation lime
authors: Marcello Ermido Chiodini; Fulvia Tambone; Marco Carozzi; Mattia Sanna; Silvia Salati; Fabrizio Adani; Marco Acutis; Alessia Perego
abstract: A two-year experiment was carried out in a paddy field to investigate the effects of the use of defecation lime derived from treated sewage sludge on soil total and soil phytoavailable heavy metals concentration.Heavy metals concentration was determined also in raw rice.Four treatments were arranged in a completely randomized block design: not fertilised (T0), organic fertilisation + chemical fertilisers (T1), defecation lime + chemical fertilisers (T2), defecation lime at pre-sowing (T3).For T3, the pH value increased significantly at the end of the second year, increasing from 5.8 to 6.11.T3 resulted in the highest soil organic carbon content (9.4 g kg -1 ), suggesting the potential of defecation lime both as soil corrective material and soil amendment.The application of defecation lime in the paddy field did not result in an increased phytoavailable amount of heavy metals in soil.

title: Influence of different soil moisture levels on boron behavior in sunflower nutrition
authors: N Zerrari; D Moustaoui; Marc Verloo
abstract: The effect of different soil water regimes on the behaviour of boron on the nutrition of sunflower has been studied on a calcareous soil and a noncalcareous soil in a greenhouse pot experiment. The results obtained showed that the different parts of sunflower (leaves, steam, head, roots) were affected by the decrease of water availability. The reductions observed vary from 2.5 to 50.3%, 4.8 to 31.7% and 4.8 to 65.3%, for dry matter, boron concentration and boron uptake respectively. The different parts of sunflower reacted with the same intensity. The mean reductions observed in the dry matter were 21.7%, 23.1%, 23.9% and 23.9% for the leaves, the steam, the head and the roots respectively. Those observed in boron uptake were 32.8%, 34.9%, 32.5% and 36.1% for the leaves, the steam, the head and the roots respectively. This decrease was more important for the calcareous soil compared to the non-calcareous soil. Boron translocation from roots to shoots varied from 45.4 to 57.0%, 17.3 to 21.1% and 17.0 to 22.2% for the leaves, the steam and the head respectively.

title: COMPLEXATION DU CA++ PAR LES SUBSTANCES HUMIQUES EXTRAITES DE TOURBE NATURELLE ET DE TOURBE TRAITEE AUX OXYDES D'AZOTE
authors: Michel Kaemmerer; Agnès Maritchù Guiresse; Mohamed Hafidi; G. Brun; Lydie Seibane; Jean-Claude Revel
abstract: The study of the complexation of calcium by humic substances (SH) extracted from a natural peat (TN) and from a peat treated with nitrogen oxides (TT) was followed by conductimetry and potentiometry with pH variable and pH constant. The complexing capacity increases as the pH rises: complexed calcium is 130 cmol kg*[-1) SH (TN) and 135 cmol kg*[-1) SH (TT) with pH 5, and 330 cmol kg*[-1) SH (TN) and 410 cmol kg*[-1) SH (TT) with pH 9. These reactions involve various functional groupings of pKa1 < 4 for TN and TT, pKa2 = 5.9 for TN and pKa2 = 6.2 for TT; in all cases, the medium has exhibited an increase in acidity. The complexation of calcium by HS extracted from TT could then enhance the efficiency of the phosphatic nutrition of plants.

abstract: [L'obiettivo di questo studio consisteva nell'indagare sul rapporto fra il contenuto di zolfo del suolo, estratto mediante estraenti diversi, e la produzione di sostanza secca e le quantita' di zolfo assorbito dalla pianta. Nella prima raccolta, lo zolfo estratto con soluzione di KH2PO4 presentava la massima correlazione con lo zolfo assorbito dalle piante, seguito da S riducibile con HI, mentre la correlazione piu' bassa si riscontrava con l'estrazione mediante KCl. Lo zolfo delle radici non presentava alcuna correlazione con il tipo di estraente. La produzione di sostanza secca era correlata con lo zolfo estratto con KH2PO4 e con S riducibile con HI. Nella seconda raccolta, l'unica correlazione individuata era quella fra S estratto mediante KH2PO4 e S assorbito dalle piante].
